item.title: Ticket #704 (protected pages don't ask for password) updated
item.dc:creator: gbhugo
item.description: Patch changed

item.title: Ticket #704 (protected pages don't ask for password) created
item.dc:creator: gbhugo
item.description:
I created a page as a subpage of another page. I set a password on this subpage. When visiting the site with another browser where I wasn't logged in to WordPress, the page fully showed up in the browser - no password was asked. The page was told to be protected in the management, but the password just wasn't asked.

The speciality of this page might be that it was empty - I have some scripts that create page templates and I set up empty pages that just select this template to show it's stuff.

item.title: Ticket #702 (add category_save_pre filter) updated
item.dc:creator: kellan
item.description:
Actually, you should probably ignore that first suggestion. spending a little more time with the 1.5 codebase, I found the 'preprocess_comment' filter. It would be more generally useful not to mention add to the consistency to use add a similar preprocess_post filter.

I've attached a patch to do this.

item.title: Ticket #407 (import-mt.php does not recognise breaks between entries) updated
item.dc:creator: anonymousbugger
item.description:
I didn't export it from MT, I put text data from another journalling tool into MT export format. Rather than go through the entire dump altering the order, I guess I will just import it all into 1.2 and then upgrade.

Is there any particular reason why WP specifies the order and the MT specs don't? Also, any reason why this was added to 1.5 when it isn't in 1.2?

item.title: Ticket #703 (comment approval status ought to be reloaded after comment_post hook) updated
item.dc:creator: fwenzel
item.description: Okay, recent completion of source code with new hooks makes it possible to change everything flawlessly when the correct hooks are used. So close this, please, and sorry for the inconvenience.

item.title: Ticket #703 (comment approval status ought to be reloaded after comment_post hook) updated
item.dc:creator: fwenzel
item.description: Patch changed

item.title: Ticket #703 (comment approval status ought to be reloaded after comment_post hook) created
item.dc:creator: fwenzel
item.description:
In functions-post.php, there's the comment_post hook:

do_action('comment_post', $comment_id);

afterwards, moderator notification is done if applicable. But what if a plugin, attached to the comment_post hook, changed the "approved" status of the comment to "unapproved"? Then the "new comment" notification is sent although the comment is in fact *held for moderation*.

So I suggest that the $approved variable is reloaded out of the database after the plugin hook for more flexibily in writing plugins.

item.dc:creator: anonymousbugger
item.description:
Here are the upgrade warnings, with the admin-functions.php include commented out of upgrade-functions.php: Warning: Invalid argument supplied for foreach() in /data/apache/htdocs/donko.org/laen/wp-settings.php on line 97

Looks like a plugin thing.

item.title: Ticket #627 (upgrade.php fails from 1.2.2 to latest 1.5 nightly) updated
item.dc:creator: anonymousbugger
item.description:
I'm also trying to upgrade from 1.2.2 to the latest CVS snapshot.

As of the current CVS revision (10 minutes ago), the problem's still there, but yeah, if you simply comment out the:

require_once(dirname(FILE) . '/admin-functions.php');

at line 3 of wp-admin/upgrade-functions.php, the upgrade progresses and succeeds (with a couple other PHP warnings).

-Laen

item.title: Ticket #407 (import-mt.php does not recognise breaks between entries) updated
item.dc:creator: 2fargon
item.description:
I tried importing it. The import did not work because each entry is expected to have "AUTHOR: ... " on the first line, and then the other items. I know that this is different from what's given in the example file at ​http://www.movabletype.org/docs/mtimport.html , but that's the way the actual files exported by MovableType look like.

WordPress identifies the beginning of a new post by looking for -------- followed by a CRLF (\r, \n, or \r\n to be precise), followed by "AUTHOR:".

I have uploaded an edited version of your file. All I did was make the first line the AUTHOR line.

Which version of MT did you export the entries from?

item.description:

I would be grateful if you could confirm that this test file imports correctly in 1.2 and I don't just have a rogue installation :)

item.title: Ticket #696 (several problems with upload.php) updated
item.dc:creator: mdawaffe
item.description: Patch changed

item.title: Ticket #696 (several problems with upload.php) created
item.dc:creator: mdawaffe
item.description:
1. option fileupload_minlevel only prevents low level users from seeing the upload tab. They can still upload files if they know upload.php's URI.
  1. The alt property of img tag is always blank in the example "code to display [the newly uploaded image]".
  1. When a duplicate file is found, the user is given the option to choose a different filename. By default that different filename is whatever_01.ext. however, in the "File uploaded!" message page, the underscore is stripped, and the user is told the newly uploaded file is called whatever01.ext both in the example HTML code and the File Details section.
  1. The file size as reported in the File Details section is always 0.
  1. The "Upload another" link is outside the div box.

item.title: Ticket #695 (template-functions-post.php uses array_fill) updated
item.dc:creator: gbhugo
item.description: Dang. Of course it's not administration but user visible: it shows up as soon as you create sub-pages. Please re-categorize (I can't find where I could recategorize myself).

item.title: Ticket #695 (template-functions-post.php uses array_fill) updated
item.dc:creator: gbhugo
item.description: Patch changed

item.title: Ticket #695 (template-functions-post.php uses array_fill) created
item.dc:creator: gbhugo
item.description: array_fill is only available up from PHP 4.2 and so this doesn't work with 4.1.2 that is in Debian stable. And the use of array_fill in that special case is actually rather silly: it's only used as an overcomplicated use of str_repeat. The patch changes from array_fill to str_repeat and so makes this work with 4.1.2 again.

70:

item.title: Ticket #694 ("Permalink structure updated" misleading.) updated
item.dc:creator: mdawaffe
item.description: Patch changed

item.title: Ticket #694 ("Permalink structure updated" misleading.) created
item.dc:creator: mdawaffe
item.description:
If your .htaccess file is not writeable, you still get a "Permalink structure updated" message after changing your permalink structure (the database has been updated, but your .htaccess has not).

The only notice you get about .htaccess is at the bottom of the page, which can easily be overlooked.

Altering the message to read "Permalink structure updated, but see message _below_" (with an #anchor link) in the case of a non-writeable .htaccess file would make things more clear.

item.title: Ticket #627 (upgrade.php fails from 1.2.2 to latest 1.5 nightly) updated
item.dc:creator: ryan
item.description:
If they query for autoload options fails, get_alloptions() will retry the query without specifying autoload. This is to accommodate 1.2.x databases which do not have the autoload field. However, before retrying the query, get_alloptions() includes upgrade-functions so it can get at make_db_current_silent(). upgrade-functions in turn calls admin-functions. admin-functions makes calls to () which is a problem for this include chain since we haven't completed all of the includes in wp-settings. We're still working on classes. Moving wp-l10n higher up in wp-settings fixes this particular problem but exposes problems where admin-functions is referring to $wp_rewrite. Since we're in the process of instantiating $wp_rewrite, it does not yet exist. So the fix is either to avoid including upgrade-functions in get_alloptions() or avoid including admin-functions from upgrade-functions. I opted to avoid including admin-functions. We only needed one function, get_home_path(), which I simply copied to upgrade-functions.

So, please retest upgrades and tell me if there is still a problem.

edited on: 01-15-05 00:17

item.title: Changeset [2095]: Do not include admin-functions from ugrade-functions to avoid circular ...
item.dc:creator: rboren
item.description: Do not include admin-functions from ugrade-functions to avoid circular dependency. Move wp-l10n higher up in the wp-settings include chain. Bug 627.
